item.title: Can you draw God?
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Baggage (For Corriere della Sera, 2010) – "An image is language without lies. Every person in the world can read an image, so it's not important where you come from." Hide Caption 2 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Pencil (For CNN Style, 2016) – "Across all creative disciplines, the pencil is the best tool of the mind. When I was thinking about Italian style, design, arts ... how good it all is, I thought that, in an ironic way, maybe God is in the pencil. I had decided to break the pencil before, but it was only when I saw the triangle did I think about God." Hide Caption 3 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Brain (For La Lettura, 2012) – " [Artist] Paul Klee said that design has its own intelligence. You have to be receptive to understand when the drawing is telling you something. Respond as you create." Hide Caption 4 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Disaster (For Corriere della Sera, 2011) – "Everything is political. I have my opinion, and I don't want to be superficial. I try to present a visual paradox, or something that can capture the reader's attention. The important thing is not to be banal." Hide Caption 5 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Exploitation (For Giunti Editore, 2011) – "I have been banal many times, but I don't show those images to anyone -- they go in the bin. It's important to be critical with yourself. You might have a lot of ideas, but if they're too obvious and you are not able to understand that, it's a shame!" Hide Caption 6 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Italy (For Corriere della Serra, 2013) – "In Italy, very few people know what an illustrator is, but in the USA illustrators are artists. So I don't think the distinction is important. As Milton Glaser said, 'Art is work,' so I am an artist because I work!" Hide Caption 7 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Identity (For La Lettura, 2012) – "I think that young people want to have experiences. They understand that with new media, computers, it doesn't give you this. So it's important in schools -- I do this in my own classrooms -- to work in the old ways. To understand the materials. If you have this then you can transfer it to new media." Hide Caption 8 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Manipulation (For Corriere della Serra, 2013) – "The computer has changed the market. Today if I had to create seven illustrations in a week, in watercolor, it would be impossible. But those traditional techniques give you something that is important in life, a process where you have to wait -- a complete contrast to today's frenetic media." Hide Caption 9 of 10 10 photos: God is in the pencil: The illustrated world of Beppe Giacobbe Taboo (Corriere della Serra, 2009) – "It's important to be fresh and simple, popular but not obvious. Looking at the work in Visual Dictionary, I think they chose all the times were I was both simple and rich." Hide Caption 10 of 10 Story highlights
